thread.title: Bishop Ford prevails, earns first trip to Glens Falls
thread.title_full: Bishop Ford prevails, earns first trip to Glens Falls - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Bishop Ford prevails, earns first trip to Glens Falls
text:
Goldfield for News Chaz Williams scored 32 points and dished 12 assists as the Falcons captured the CHSAA Class 'A' state title in a 72-62 victory over Chaminade on Sunday at Fordham University. When point guard Chaz Williams walks into the Bishop Ford locker room every day to get changed for practice, he can't miss the big sign that hangs prominently on the wall. The words, displayed in bold letters, are "Hard work, determination, sacrifice and commitment," but they also ought to add "unselfishness."
Williams scored 32 points and dished 12 assists as the Falcons captured the CHSAA Class 'A' state title in a 72-62 victory over Chaminade on Sunday at Fordham University .
The 5-8, Hofstra -bound senior broke through the Long Island champions' defense with his customary speed and athleticism. He was equally deadly with accurate passes to Tyrik Tucker (14 points) and others as the Falcons worked together to stave off Chaminade's late fourth quarter comeback.
"Determination. It's the biggest word in this team," Williams said afterward. "I'm a point guard. I think point guard first. I think pass first. I will never be a shoot-first point guard, because it's not my job. It's not my role."
There is little doubt that Bishop Ford, which has now won 18 straight games, is one of the hottest teams in the city. In increasing their overall record to 23-5, the Falcons earned a berth in the state Federation tournament in Glens Falls later this month.
Bishop Ford head coach John Infortunio watched his team cut down the Fordham nets - the culmination of a journey that continues to amaze him.
After the team waged a successful second-half comeback to win the city title on March 7 over Iona Prep, the Falcons continue to inspire their coach.
"They fought and they fought; they never let me down," Infortunio said. "When I was down, they picked me up. When they were down, I picked them up. It's been that kind of thing all year. ... I just enjoyed watching them celebrate today."
Bishop Ford, which led for most of the game, didn't panic when the Flyers (19-6) made a late push. Sean Wilde scored a team-high 28 points, scoring 14 straight points to cut a lead that was 62-47 early in the fourth to 68-62 with 33 seconds remaining in the game.
Senior guard Don Marbury came off the bench and notched two free throws with 27.8 seconds left, sealing Bishop Ford's first trip to Glens Falls.
PSAL 'B' BOYS
FIELD'S DOWN TO 4 IN 'B'
Acorn 86, Hunter 59
Top-seeded Acorn overcame a 24-15 first-quarter deficit to eliminate Hunter on Wednesday behind senior guard Rameek Doughty's 23 points. The Panthers also got double-doubles from Shervoyn Forbes (17 points, 14 rebounds), Charles Goddard (15 points, 15 rebounds) and Christophe Walker (16 points, 13 rebounds) as they advanced to the semifinals to face No. 20 EBC/ Bushwick at Lehman College on Tuesday (7 p.m.).
The 'B' league championship game is scheduled for Saturday at St. Francis College (3 p.m.).
EBC/Bushwick 69, Townsend Harris 59
No. 20 EBC/Bushwick continued its unlikely run through the playoffs, knocking out No. 5 Townsend Harris at Lehman College on Wednesday. Senior forward Jose Stable paced the Panthers' offense with 29 points and 17 rebounds. Bushwick squares off against No. 1 Acorn in the semifinals on Wednesday.
SSLJR 74, Richard Green 65
Secondary School for Law, Journalism & Re-search eliminated No. 6 Richard Green at Hunter College on Thursday behind a balanced attack that saw four players score in double figures. Joshua Ramirez (19 points), Akeem Ellis (18 points, 12 rebounds), Andrew Edwards (15 points, 12 rebounds) and Vidal Callender (14 points) all came up big for the Panthers. Third-seeded SSLJR battles No. 2 Brooklyn Collegiate in the semifinals at Lehman College on Tuesday at (5 p.m.).
Brooklyn Collegiate 74, Taft 69
Brooklyn Collegiate outscored No. 7 Taft 23-6 in the fourth quarter to pull off a victory on Thursday. Senior guard Damon White led the Lions with 24 points and junior guard Dwight Gist chipped in with 18 points. The No. 2 Lions advance to the semifinals and will face No. 3 SSLJR.
- Matt Kersner
